newsitem.title: USA: Calif. public utilities support restructuring.
newsitem.headline: Calif. public utilities support restructuring.

text.p: California's public utility industry supports the restructuring legislation recently signed by Governor Pete Wilson, the California Municipal Utilities Association (CMUA) said on Thursday.

The legislation "is a balanced approach to reaching a competitive electric generation market that also protects the interests of all California consumers," said Bill Carnahan, general manager of the Riverside Public Utilities Department and chairman of the CMUA task force on restructuring.

While it does not mandate retail competition for publicly owned utilities, the state legislation is expected to create a strong incentive for those utilities to participate in the restructured industry.
"We fully expect market forces to dictate retail competition for all California customers," said Carnahan.
Under the state law, residential and small business customers of investor-owned utilities will receive a 10 percent rate reduction starting in 1998.

The legislation does not impose a similar rate reduction requirement on publicly owned utilities, but their rates are already up to 30 percent lower than investor-owned utilities to their residential customers, CMUA noted.
